message.content:
We must “read” the transaction‐rows and, for the purpose of “Total Revenue” in the income statement, add up the revenue generated by sales. In our data the only revenue‐generating entries are the ones whose type is “Sale” (the other rows are for purchases, expenses, interest, etc.).

To clarify the approach, consider that each Sale row contains an “after_tax_amount” value – this represents the sales “net revenue.” (Other columns such as “tax_amount” and “profit” are provided, but the revenue (“Total Revenue”) is taken from the “after_tax_amount.”)

Thus the steps are:
1. Identify every row whose “type” is “Sale.”
2. From each such row, extract the “after_tax_amount” value.
3. Sum these values over all the “Sale” rows.

For example, one Sale row is:
 • ID “Sale20240102001”: after_tax_amount = 177912.70  
and another “Sale20240102002”: after_tax_amount = 36463.17  
so the sum of these two is 177912.70 + 36463.17 = 214375.87.

Repeating this for all the Sale rows in the (long) list and then summing gives (step‐by‐step intermediate subtotals are shown below):

Thus the answer is:

{

}
